elements.content: Low melting organic esters, ethyl acetate (1), diethyl carbonate (2), methyl benzoate (3) and phenyl acetate (4), have been grown using the miniature zone melting in situ crystallization technique and their molecular and crystal structures have been determined. Co-crystallization of the esters 1–4 with Lewis acid 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)tetrafluorobenzene (II) resulted in three adducts with a ratio of organic to organometallic components of 1:1 (II·1, II·3, and II·4), and one complex with a corresponding ratio of 1:2 (2(II)·2). X-ray analysis revealed presence of supramolecular 1D chain associates in crystals of II·1 and II·3, which are similar to those found before in the crystal of individual II. The crystal structures of complexes 2(II)·2 and II·4 have demonstrated the presence of 2D layer supramolecular associates. Both 1D and 2D associates are stabilized mostly by strong Hg···Cl interactions between molecules of II, which in some cases are additionally strengthen via Hg···O, Hg···π, and π–π interactions between molecules of esters and II. Clear correlation between type of supramolecular associates and crystal morphology was found: complexes with 1D supramolecular associates grow in the form of needle-like crystals, while 2D associates promote formation of the plate-like crystals. Comparison of structural characteristics of esters 1–4 in crystals of individual compounds, complexes, and isolated state (quantum calculations and gas electron diffraction literature data) has demonstrated similarity of the molecular geometry but possibility of conformational variations. On the basis of correlation analysis of structural and IR spectroscopic data on all compounds under investigation and taking into account that sum of the van der Waals radii of the Hg and O is equal to 3.50 Å, it was shown that shorter Hg···O contacts should correspond to an additional interactions between these types of atoms.

elements.content: Low-melting organic esters, ethyl acetate, diethyl carbonate, methyl benzoate, and phenyl acetate, have been grown using the miniature zone melting in situ crystallization technique and their molecular and crystal structures have been determined. The complexes of 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)tetrafluorobenzene with those esters have been synthesized and structurally characterized. By comparison of their IR data and their structure, we have found that sum of the van der Waals radii of the Hg and O is equal to 3.50 Å.

elements.content: Bidentate 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)benzene, o-(C6H4)(HgCl)2 (I), and 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)tetrafluorobenzene, o-(C6F4)(HgCl)2 (II) or cyclic tridentate perfluoro-o-phenylmercury, o-(C6F4Hg)3 (III), Lewis acids (LA) presented in Scheme easily form adducts (molecular complexes, guest–host structures, co-crystals) with organic ionic and neutral electron-reach compounds. Adduct formation can influence catalytic activity and solid state polymerization, prevent decomposition of unstable guest-molecules, transform spectral behavior of guests, etc. Numerous examples of complexes of LA III have been studied and their structure, properties and applications have been described in reviews by Shur and Tikhonova and Gabbai et al.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Bidentate 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)benzene, o-(C6H4)(HgCl)2 (I), and 1,2-bis(chloromercurio)tetrafluorobenzene, o-(C6F4)(HgCl)2 (II) or cyclic tridentate perfluoro-o-phenylmercury, o-(C6F4Hg)3 (III), Lewis acids (LA) presented in Scheme  easily form adducts (molecular complexes, guest-host structures, co-crystals) with organic ionic and neutral electron-reach compounds. Adduct formation can influence catalytic activity and solid state polymerization, prevent decomposition of unstable guest-molecules, transform spectral behavior of guests, etc. Numerous examples of complexes of LA III have been studied and their structure, properties and applications have been described in reviews by Shur and Tikhonova and Gabbai et al.

<label>1</label>

</fig>

A smaller number of complexes with LA I and II have been characterized. Because of low ability of Hg atoms of I to participate in the Hg intermolecular interactions not many adducts with I are found. On the contrary, fluorinated species II form adducts with a variety of compounds containing terminal oxo, nitrilo, or nitrile functionalities. It was quite obvious that main factors determining crystal structure of such adducts are intermolecular interactions between LA and guest molecules and between LA molecules, where dominant interactions necessarily include Hg and Cl atoms. This assumption is supported by observation of supramolecular associates of LA II with benzaldehyde and nitrotoluenes, which structures are not disturbed significantly by introduction of different guest molecules. It was shown that supramolecular organization in crystals of these compounds enforces particular orientation of the guest molecules leading to a formation in some cases acentric structures. Recently, direct reflection of supramolecular organization in crystal was found in macroscopic crystal properties such as crystal shape. In addition, supramolecular organization in crystals influences spectral characteristics of groups involved in intermolecular interactions. Such examples were found for complexes of oxygen containing molecules with LA II and III.

elements.content: In the present work, structures of several liquids at room temperature aliphatic and aromatic esters 1–4 (Scheme ) were characterized with X-ray diffraction analysis. To the best of our knowledge, crystalline structures of mentioned esters have never been studied before as individual compounds. Adducts of 1–4 with LA II (Scheme ) were also obtained and their structures were analyzed with respect of formation molecular associates, supramolecular structures and correlation with crystal morphology and their spectroscopic characteristics. For analysis of formation of molecular associates and evaluation of influence of intermolecular interactions on molecular structure some spectroscopic studies and quantum-chemical calculations have been carried out.

For analysis of formation of molecular associates and evaluation of influence of intermolecular interactions on molecular structure some spectroscopic studies and quantum-chemical calculations have been carried out.

On the basis of the data obtained, an approach to an evaluation of the van der Waals radii for the Hg atom in some containing organometallic compounds is discussed.

Experimental Section

Compound II was prepared and purified according to the published procedure. All other reagents for adducts preparation were obtained commercially and used without further purification. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 FT-IR spectrometer over the frequency range 4000–400 cm–1 using the Nujol mulls technique.

elements.content: Ethyl acetate (mp 190 K), diethyl carbonate (mp 198 K), methyl benzoate (mp 258 K), and phenyl acetate (mp 259 K) each were drawn into a 0.3 mm diameter Lindemann capillary (∼20 mm length). Capillaries were sealed at both ends with standard butane burner and attached to a goniometr head, which was mounted on a diffractometer, equipped with a CRYO-FLEX low-temperature device and Optical Heating Crystallization Device (OHCD) for laser-assisted crystallization (CO2 laser, λ = 10.57–10.63 μm). The polycrystalline solids were obtained by freezing on 30K below melting point. Then the temperature of solids was elevated up to 10 K below melting point. After that, using a laser heating (2.0 W laser power), we established solid–liquid equilibrium on a narrow zone of the capillary, and crystals were grown by applying the same laser power. The laser power was subsequently reduced to zero over a period of 20 min at the end of the crystallization cycle. After that single crystals were cooled down to 100 K and X-ray data collection was performed.
elements.clean_text:
In situ Low-Temperature Crystallization of Compounds 1-4 

Ethyl acetate (mp 190 K), diethyl carbonate (mp 198 K), methyl benzoate (mp 258 K), and phenyl acetate (mp 259 K) each were drawn into a 0.3 mm diameter Lindemann capillary (~20 mm length). Capillaries were sealed at both ends with standard butane burner and attached to a goniometr head, which was mounted on a diffractometer, equipped with a CRYO-FLEX low-temperature device and Optical Heating Crystallization Device (OHCD) for laser-assisted crystallization (CO2 laser, λ = 10.57-10.63 μm). The polycrystalline solids were obtained by freezing on 30K below melting point. Then the temperature of solids was elevated up to 10 K below melting point. After that, using a laser heating (2.0 W laser power), we established solid-liquid equilibrium on a narrow zone of the capillary, and crystals were grown by applying the same laser power. The laser power was subsequently reduced to zero over a period of 20 min at the end of the crystallization cycle. After that single crystals were cooled down to 100 K and X-ray data collection was performed.

elements.content: Liquid at room temperature ester was added to compound II. The mixture was heated to give a homogeneous solution, from which colorless single crystals of complex were obtained upon cooling to room temperature. Crystals of complex were filtered, washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL), and air-dried. All complexes were obtained with quantitative yield. Freshly obtained crystals were used for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. On air transparent crystals of adducts were rapidly transformed to a white powder.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for Preparation of the 1,2-Bis(chloromercurio) tetrafluorobenzene (II) Adducts with Esters 1-4 

Liquid at room temperature ester was added to compound II. The mixture was heated to give a homogeneous solution, from which colorless single crystals of complex were obtained upon cooling to room temperature. Crystals of complex were filtered, washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL), and air-dried. All complexes were obtained with quantitative yield. Freshly obtained crystals were used for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. On air transparent crystals of adducts were rapidly transformed to a white powder.

elements.content: Crystal data, details of data collection, and structure refinement parameters for complexes II·1–II·4 are presented in Table , the same information for compounds 1–4 is presented in Table . X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out with a Bruker SMART APEX II difractometr with CCD area detector (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, ω-scans with a 0.5° step in ω) at 100 K. Semiempirical method SADABS was applied for absorption correction for compounds 1–4 and complexes II·1 and II·3. For other complexes a numerical absorption correction has been applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares technique against F 2 with anisotropic temperature parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All H atoms, except for H atoms in compound 1, were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. The hydrogen atoms in compound 1 were placed at ideal positions and their positional and U iso(H) values were freely refined. Data reduction and further calculations were performed using Bruker SAINT+ and SHELXTL NT program packages.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Crystal data, details of data collection, and structure refinement parameters for complexes II⋅1-II⋅4 are presented in Table , the same information for compounds 1-4 is presented in Table . X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out with a Bruker SMART APEX II difractometr with CCD area detector (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, ω-scans with a 0.5° step in ω) at 100 K. Semiempirical method SADABS was applied for absorption correction for compounds 1-4 and complexes II⋅1 and II⋅3. For other complexes a numerical absorption correction has been applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares technique against F 2 with anisotropic temperature parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All H atoms, except for H atoms in compound 1, were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. The hydrogen atoms in compound 1 were placed at ideal positions and their positional and U iso(H) values were freely refined. Data reduction and further calculations were performed using Bruker SAINT+ and SHELXTL NT program packages.

During refinement of crystal structure of complex II·4 it was found two high positive residual density peaks: 12.03 e Å–3 near the Hg(2B) center (at distance 1.76 Å) and 11.44 e Å–3 near the Hg(1B) center (distance 1.80 Å). The interpretation of these peaks as Hg, Cl, C, or O atoms did not give positive results, so these peaks were probably related to crystal twinning. However, it was not possible to find the TWIN matrix for this crystal using the CELL_NOW, ROTAX, or APEX2 software. Setting up the X-ray diffraction experiment with a new crystal of II·4 resulted to similar or even worse peaks of residual density. Therefore we did not discuss the molecular geometry of this complex; however, we used the experimental results for qualitative structure characterization.

The interpretation of these peaks as Hg, Cl, C, or O atoms did not give positive results, so these peaks were probably related to crystal twinning. However, it was not possible to find the TWIN matrix for this crystal using the CELL_NOW, ROTAX, or APEX2 software. Setting up the X-ray diffraction experiment with a new crystal of II⋅4 resulted to similar or even worse peaks of residual density. Therefore we did not discuss the molecular geometry of this complex; however, we used the experimental results for qualitative structure characterization.

elements.content:
Crystal morphology (Miller indices of crystal faces) was estimated using goniometer of the APEX II diffractometer and corresponding APEX2 software.

Computational Details

Quantum-chemical calculations of the geometry of isolated molecules of esters 1–4 were performed. All calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 03 program package. Geometry and atomic charges of molecules 1–4 were optimized with DFT calculations (B3LYP in conjunction with the 6-311++G** basic set) and ab initio method (MP2 in conjunction with the 6-31G** basis set). The structures were visualized using program packages SHELXTL NT, DIMOND 2, and MERCURY.

Crystal morphology (Miller indices of crystal faces) was estimated using goniometer of the APEX II diffractometer and corresponding APEX2 software. 

Computational Details

Quantum-chemical calculations of the geometry of isolated molecules of esters 1-4 were performed. All calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 03 program package. Geometry and atomic charges of molecules 1-4 were optimized with DFT calculations (B3LYP in conjunction with the 6-311++G** basic set) and ab initio method (MP2 in conjunction with the 6-31G** basis set). The structures were visualized using program packages SHELXTL NT, DIMOND 2, and MERCURY.

elements.content: The single crystals of the low melting esters 1–4 were grown by in situ crystallization techniqe at temperatures 10K below their melting points. After that temperature was decreased to 100K, at which diffraction experiments were performed. It was found that the compounds 2 and 4 are crystallized in noncentrosymmetric (Pna21 and P212121, respectively), while the two other (compounds 1 and 3) in centrosymmetric (P1̅ and Pbca) space groups. The isomers 3 and 4 crystallize in orthorhombic space groups with two similar unit cell parameters (Table ), however in the centrosymmetric unit cell of 3 the third parameter is twice larger than in 4. Aliphatic esters 1 and 2 contain two and four independent molecules in the asymmetric unit, while aromatic esters 3 and 4 have only one independent molecule in the unit cell.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Crystal Structures of Esters

The single crystals of the low melting esters 1-4 were grown by in situ crystallization techniqe at temperatures 10K below their melting points. After that temperature was decreased to 100K, at which diffraction experiments were performed. It was found that the compounds 2 and 4 are crystallized in noncentrosymmetric (Pna21 and P212121, respectively), while the two other (compounds 1 and 3) in centrosymmetric (P1̅ and Pbca) space groups. The isomers 3 and 4 crystallize in orthorhombic space groups with two similar unit cell parameters (Table ), however in the centrosymmetric unit cell of 3 the third parameter is twice larger than in 4. Aliphatic esters 1 and 2 contain two and four independent molecules in the asymmetric unit, while aromatic esters 3 and 4 have only one independent molecule in the unit cell.

elements.content: Molecular structures of the compounds 1–4 in crystal are presented in Figures –. Comparison of the geometrical parameters of 1–4 with analogous values from the gas phase and quantum calculations is presented in the (Tables 1S–4S). It can be seen that the bond lengths and bond angles in compounds 1-4 are very similar to those found previously in quantum calculations and electron diffraction. The main differences in structural data for 1-4 are values of the torsion angles. Therefore our discussion on compounds 1–4 is mostly focused on these molecular characteristics.

elements.content: The ethyl acetate (1) (Figure a and Table 1S) contains two independent molecules (A and B) in the asymmetric unit. Both molecules have similar geometrical parameters and symmetry close to C s . The torsion angles C(1)–O(2)–C(3)–C(4) are equal to 178.8(2) and 177.0(2)° in molecules A and B, respectively, so in the crystal of 1 we have only trans conformers, however in the gas phase two conformers of ethyl acetate (trans and gauche) were found by electron diffraction study. The torsion angle C(1)–O(2)–C(3)–C(4) in gauche conformation of 1 is equal to 79°. It was pointed out by authors that trans conformation is more stable than gauche, that might explain the absence of gauche form in the crystal of 1.

elements.content: No short contacts between the ester molecules (Figure b) were found in crystal of 1. Molecules are packed in layers which are parallel to crystallographic plane bc. Figure c shows that each layer contains only one type of the symmetrically independent molecules (A or B). Molecular packing of 1 consists of alternating A and B molecular layers.

elements.content: Diethyl carbonate (2) in the crystal (Figure a) contains four symmetrically independent molecules (A, B, C and D) which have similar geometry (Table 2S). The torsion angles C(1)–O(2)–C(2)–C(3) and C(1)–O(3)–C(4)–C(5) slightly deviate from 180° (173.5(1)-179.5(1)°), while values of torsion angles O(1)–C(1)–O(2)-C(2) and O(1)–C(1)–O(3)–C(4) are close to 0° (1.0(2)–4.5(2)°). So in the crystal of 2 we have four molecules which are close to the most stable conformer.

elements.content: In the crystal molecules 2 are packed in the corrugated layers (Figures c–e), which are parallel to the crystallographic plane ac. Each of these layers contains two of four symmetrically independent molecules A and C or B and D, hence crystal of 2 has two types of layers (AC and BD). The orientation of molecules 2 in both layers AC and BD is almost perpendicular to each other (Figures c, d). In Figure e molecular packing with alternating positions of layers AC and BD is presented.

elements.content: The molecular structure of methyl benzoate 3 is shown in Figure a. The molecular geometry of the carbonyl fragment in 3 and aliphatic esters are essentially the same. Also, in compound 3 the ipso-angle C(4)C(2)C(8) at the carboxyl group is equal group to 120.4(1)° that represents practically ideal value that is different to what was found for nitrobenzene and nitrotoluenes, where similar angle at nitro group is larger than 120°.

elements.content: The dihedral angle between planes of the carboxyl and phenyl groups φ(Ph/COOMe) in 3 is equal to 23.4(4)°, while according to the previous (HF/6-31G** level) and our quantum calculations (B3LYP/6-311++G** and MP2/6-31G** levels) this angle is equal to 0° ( Table 3S). This value suggests that in crystal there is measurable conjugation between π-systems of aromatic and carbonyl groups, while in a free molecule it is even stronger. A deviation of the carboxyl fragment from the plane of aromatic fragment might be explained by the crystal packing effect, however in crystal of 3 we did not find any short contacts between ester molecules (Figure b).

A deviation of the carboxyl fragment from the plane of aromatic fragment might be explained by the crystal packing effect, however in crystal of 3 we did not find any short contacts between ester molecules (Figure b).

elements.content: The structure of phenyl acetate (4) is presented in Figure a. The most important geometrical parameters of 4 are listed in Table 4S. The majority of geometrical parameters of both isomers 3 and 4 ( Tables 3S and 4S) are similar to each other. However, the ipso-angle at the acetyl group C(8)–C(3)–C(4) is equal 122.4(1)° which is slightly larger than 120°. This fact may indicate some conjugation between lone pairs of oxygen atom O(2) and the π-system of the aromatic ring. It also can be supported by the value of dihedral angle between phenyl ring and acetyl group φ(MeCOO/Ph) which is equal to 72.7(5)°, similar to the results of quantum calculations (B3LYP/6-311++G** and MP2/6-31G** levels) where this angle is found to be 60° that exclude conjugation.

elements.content: It was found previously that compound II can easily form complexes with a variety of oxygen-containing neutral Lewis bases such as carbonyl compounds and nitrocompounds. It was shown that II reacts differently with aromatic and aliphatic compounds. For example, Lewis acid II does not form any complexes with aliphatic aldehydes and nitro compounds; however, it easily forms complexes with aromatic aldehydes and nitro compounds. It was found that the reason of such effect is a formation of strong π···π stacking interactions between aromatic ring of II and ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Complexes of Compound II with Esters 1-4 

It was found previously that compound II can easily form complexes with a variety of oxygen-containing neutral Lewis bases such as carbonyl compounds and nitrocompounds. It was shown that II reacts differently with aromatic and aliphatic compounds. For example, Lewis acid II does not form any complexes with aliphatic aldehydes and nitro compounds; however, it easily forms complexes with aromatic aldehydes and nitro compounds. It was found that the reason of such effect is a formation of strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between aromatic ring of II and ligand.

elements.content: Compound II was dissolved in small amounts of 1–4 and after recrystallization the crystals of complexes with corresponding esters were precipitating. In all cases single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were found and their structural analysis was carried out. The discussion on the structures of these complexes is presented below.
elements.clean_text: Compound II was dissolved in small amounts of 1-4 and after recrystallization the crystals of complexes with corresponding esters were precipitating. In all cases single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were found and their structural analysis was carried out. The discussion on the structures of these complexes is presented below.

elements.content: The small colorless needle-like crystals (Figure a) of complex II with ethyl acetate have a 1:1 molar ratio, {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][EtOAc]} (II·1). The structure of complex is presented in Figure b. It can be seen that ethyl acetate is chelated by mercury atoms of molecule II via carbonyl oxygen atom O(1). The Hg···O distances in this fragment (Table ) are similar (2.797(6) and 2.789(6) Å) and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg (1.73–2.00 Å) and O (1.54 Å). The plane of the acetyl fragment in 1 is almost perpendicular to that of II. The angle between bond vector CO group and plane of the molecule II is equal to 48.6°. Such chelate coordination of carbonyl compounds is typical for complexes containing II, and has been found in complexes with acetone, dimethylformamide, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Complex with Ethyl Acetate

The small colorless needle-like crystals (Figure a) of complex II with ethyl acetate have a 1:1 molar ratio, {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][EtOAc]} (II⋅1). The structure of complex is presented in Figure b. It can be seen that ethyl acetate is chelated by mercury atoms of molecule II via carbonyl oxygen atom O(1). The Hg⋅⋅⋅O distances in this fragment (Table ) are similar (2.797(6) and 2.789(6) Å) and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg (1.73-2.00 Å) and O (1.54 Å). The plane of the acetyl fragment in 1 is almost perpendicular to that of II. The angle between bond vector CO group and plane of the molecule II is equal to 48.6°. Such chelate coordination of carbonyl compounds is typical for complexes containing II, and has been found in complexes with acetone, dimethylformamide, etc.

elements.content: The main difference between previously investigated complexes and complex II·1 is the additional coordination of the carbonyl oxygen atoms with mercury atoms from the second molecule II in the centrosymmetric dimer (Figure b). It was found, that Hg...O distance in dimer of 3.491(7) Å is much longer than in the chelate, but it is still shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of O and Hg. Such additional coordination was not found before in any complexes of II. The angle Hg(1)−x+1,-y+1,–z+2–O(1)–C(8) is equal to the 124.2°, which allows to suggest that this additional coordination of O(1) atom corresponds to interaction of mercury atom Hg(1A) with a lone pair of the oxygen. Therefore it is possible to conclude that the two mercury atoms in the chelate fragment interact with a lone pair of oxygen, when the additional coordination in the dimer represents an interaction with the second oxygen lone pair. The geometry parameters in molecule 1 in complex II·1 are similar to what was found in the crystal of individual compound 1 ( Table 1S).

The angle Hg(1)-x+1,-y+1,-z+2-O(1)-C(8) is equal to the 124.2°, which allows to suggest that this additional coordination of O(1) atom corresponds to interaction of mercury atom Hg(1A) with a lone pair of the oxygen. Therefore it is possible to conclude that the two mercury atoms in the chelate fragment interact with a lone pair of oxygen, when the additional coordination in the dimer represents an interaction with the second oxygen lone pair. elements.content: The complex of II with diethyl carbonate precipitates from the solution in the form of colorless plate-like crystals (Figure a). These crystals contain two molecules of Lewis acid II per one molecule of 2, {[C6F4Hg2Cl2]2[Et2CO3]} (2(II)·2), which results to two symmetrically independent units of complex (A and B). The structure of these complexes is presented in Figures b and c for A and B, respectively. The complexes A and B are similar, however B is located in special position at the inversion center and molecule of diethyl carbonate occupies two equivalent positions around it. In our discussion we will use only one position of 2 in complex B.
elements.clean_text:
Complex with Diethyl Carbonate

The complex of II with diethyl carbonate precipitates from the solution in the form of colorless plate-like crystals (Figure a). These crystals contain two molecules of Lewis acid II per one molecule of 2, {[C6F4Hg2Cl2]2[Et2CO3]} (2(II)⋅2), which results to two symmetrically independent units of complex (A and B). The structure of these complexes is presented in Figures b and c for A and B, respectively. The complexes A and B are similar, however B is located in special position at the inversion center and molecule of diethyl carbonate occupies two equivalent positions around it. In our discussion we will use only one position of 2 in complex B.

elements.content: Complexes 2(II)·2 have a “sandwich” structure (Figure b and c), in which molecules of diethyl carbonate are located between two molecules of II and are bonded via the oxygen atoms to all four mercury atoms in both molecules of II. In this case the carbonyl oxygen atom O(1A) of 2 is bonded to the fist molecule II, while atoms O(2A) and O(3A) are bonded to the second molecule II. In a dimer, the distances Hg···O(1A) (2.726(7) and 2.884(8) Å) are much shorter than Hg···O(2A) and Hg···O(3A) (3.175(7)–3.438(7) Å); however, all these distances are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O. The molecules of II in the “sandwiches” are nearly parallel to each other (dihedral angle between the molecular planes is 4.7°). The carbonyl plane of molecule 2 is almost perpendicular to the planes of II (the dihedral angles between corresponding planes are 98.4 and 81.0°).
elements.clean_text: Complexes 2(II)⋅2 have a "sandwich" structure (Figure b and c), in which molecules of diethyl carbonate are located between two molecules of II and are bonded via the oxygen atoms to all four mercury atoms in both molecules of II. In this case the carbonyl oxygen atom O(1A) of 2 is bonded to the fist molecule II, while atoms O(2A) and O(3A) are bonded to the second molecule II. In a dimer, the distances Hg⋅⋅⋅O(1A) (2.726(7) and 2.884(8) Å) are much shorter than Hg⋅⋅⋅O(2A) and Hg⋅⋅⋅O(3A) (3.175(7)-3.438(7) Å); however, all these distances are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O. The molecules of II in the "sandwiches" are nearly parallel to each other (dihedral angle between the molecular planes is 4.7°). The carbonyl plane of molecule 2 is almost perpendicular to the planes of II (the dihedral angles between corresponding planes are 98.4 and 81.0°).

elements.content: The structure of complex 2(II)·2 is quite unusual, and it was not found in previously studied similar complexes. It might be attributed to the fact that the diethyl carbonate is the multidentate Lewis base, so not only carbonyl oxygen but also ester oxygen atoms interact with mercury atoms that allows for the formation of structure 2(II)·2. However, it should be mentioned also, that in structure of II·1 the ester oxygen O(2) does not interact with mercury atoms, probably due to the larger Lewis basicity of the esters atoms in carbonate fragment. The geometry parameters of 2 in 2(II)·2 are close to those in crystal of individual compound 2 ( Table 2S), except for a slight rotation around O(3)–C(4) bond; for instance, torsion angle C(1A)–O(3A)–C(4A)–C(5A) is equal to 160.2(9)° in 2(II)·2, while the angle C(1A)–O(2A)–C(2A)–C(3A) in 2 is close to 180°.
elements.clean_text: The structure of complex 2(II)⋅2 is quite unusual, and it was not found in previously studied similar complexes. It might be attributed to the fact that the diethyl carbonate is the multidentate Lewis base, so not only carbonyl oxygen but also ester oxygen atoms interact with mercury atoms that allows for the formation of structure 2(II)⋅2. However, it should be mentioned also, that in structure of II⋅1 the ester oxygen O(2) does not interact with mercury atoms, probably due to the larger Lewis basicity of the esters atoms in carbonate fragment. The geometry parameters of 2 in 2(II)⋅2 are close to those in crystal of individual compound 2 ( Table 2S), except for a slight rotation around O(3)-C(4) bond; for instance, torsion angle C(1A)-O(3A)-C(4A)-C(5A) is equal to 160.2(9)° in 2(II)⋅2, while the angle C(1A)-O(2A)-C(2A)-C(3A) in 2 is close to 180°.

These layers are arranged along the plane (102) and have zigzag pattern. In this case each zigzag link contains three units of complex 2(II)·2 (two A units and one B unit).

Complex of II with methyl benzoate has 1:1 molar ratio of II and 3 {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][PhCOOMe]} (II·3) and precipitates as colorless needle-like crystalline solid (Figure a). Complex II·3 has a chain structure presented in Figures b, c. elements.clean_text:
Complex with Methyl Benzoate

Complex of II with methyl benzoate has 1:1 molar ratio of II and 3 {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][PhCOOMe]} (II⋅3) and precipitates as colorless needle-like crystalline solid (Figure a). Complex II⋅3 has a chain structure presented in Figures b, c. The chains of molecules II and 3 are formed with four types of intermolecular interactions, namely, Hg⋅⋅⋅Cl, Hg⋅⋅⋅O, Hg⋅⋅⋅C, and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking.

elements.content: In the chains (Figures b, c) the neighboring molecules of II are connected via Hg···Cl contacts (Table ), which lengths are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and Cl. That shows that molecular chains in this complex are mostly stabilized by the Hg···Cl intermolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text: In the chains (Figures b, c) the neighboring molecules of II are connected via Hg⋅⋅⋅Cl contacts (Table ), which lengths are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and Cl. That shows that molecular chains in this complex are mostly stabilized by the Hg⋅⋅⋅Cl intermolecular interactions.

elements.content: Molecule of 3 is connected via carbonyl oxygen atom O(1) to the only one Hg atom (Figure d) so this interaction does not produce additional stabilization of chain. In complex II·3 interactions of oxygen atom O(2) with Hg atoms of II were not found while the contact Hg(1)···O(1) 3.217(6) Å is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O.

elements.content: The main difference between complexes with aliphatic esters and complexes with 3 is the presence of Hg···π interactions between Hg atom of II and the π-system of the phenyl ring in 3 (Figure e). The distance between aromatic ring centroid of molecule 3 (Cg) and atom Hg(1), Cg···Hg(1) is equal to 3.51 Å, which is inside interval of distances characteristic for interactions of Hg with aromatic systems. Such interaction was found before in complex II with benzene, however the similar distance in this case (3.69 Å) was much longer than in complex II·3. Another type of interactions which were found inside the chains of II·3 were the π···π stacking interactions between the carboxyl group of 3 and the tetrafulorobenzine ring of II (Figure e) that can be supported with the short C3···O(1) x,y,z−1 3.35 Å and C5···O(2) x, y,z−1 3.39 Å contacts.

Such interaction was found before in complex II with benzene, however the similar distance in this case (3.69 Å) was much longer than in complex II⋅3. Another type of interactions which were found inside the chains of II⋅3 were the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between the carboxyl group of 3 and the tetrafulorobenzine ring of II (Figure e) that can be supported with the short C3⋅⋅⋅O(1) x,y,z-1 3.35 Å and C5⋅⋅⋅O(2) x, y,z-1 3.39 Å contacts.

elements.content: In the complex II·3 molecule of 3 is connected with II via Hg···π and π···π interactions, while II, in turn, is connected with another molecule of II via Hg···O interaction; thus we may say that in this case molecule has a role of bridge between two molecules of II; therefore, it additionally stabilizes chains in the complex II·3.

elements.content: The bond lengths and bond angles in coordinated molecule 3 in complex II·3 are similar to those in the structure of uncoordinated 3. The dihedral angle between planes of the phenyl ring and carboxyl group φ(Ph/COOMe) equal to 12(1)°, is smaller than in crystal of 3 (23.4(4)°. The decrease of the φ(Ph/COOMe) angle probably can be explained by the participating of the acetyl group in the π···π stacking interaction. It can be seen from Figure f, that chains of II·3 are extended along crystallographic direction [001] and do not participate in any strong interactions between each other.

elements.content: According to crystallographic data (Table ) complex II·3 crystallizes in noncentrosymmetric monoclinic space group Cc, which is interesting because uncoordinated 3 crystallizes in centrosymmetric group Pbca, so it presents one more example where supramolecular organization involving Hg nonbonded interactions can produce acentric structure of polar molecules.

elements.content: The complex of II with phenyl acetate exists in a form of colorless plate-like crystals (Figure a) and contains one molecule of Lewis acid per one molecule of Lewis base ligand {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][MeCOOPh]} (II·4). The crystals of complex II·4 contains two aggregates (A and B) in the asymmetric unit. The structure of these aggregates is presented in Figure b. In complex II·4, the carbonyl oxygen atom O(1) is chelated by two mercury atoms of II. The bond lengths Hg···O(1) are in the range 2.79(3)–2.83(3) Å (Table ), which is significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii. Another interesting observation is that the mercury atom Hg(2) interacts with the aromatic ring of molecule 4 via Hg···π bond. The corresponding distances Hg(2)···Cg (where Cg is the centroid of the phenyl ring in 4) are 3.46 amd 3.48 Å , for aggregates of A and B, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Complex with Phenyl Acetate

The complex of II with phenyl acetate exists in a form of colorless plate-like crystals (Figure a) and contains one molecule of Lewis acid per one molecule of Lewis base ligand {[C6F4Hg2Cl2][MeCOOPh]} (II⋅4). The crystals of complex II⋅4 contains two aggregates (A and B) in the asymmetric unit. The structure of these aggregates is presented in Figure b. In complex II⋅4, the carbonyl oxygen atom O(1) is chelated by two mercury atoms of II. The bond lengths Hg⋅⋅⋅O(1) are in the range 2.79(3)-2.83(3) Å (Table ), which is significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii. Another interesting observation is that the mercury atom Hg(2) interacts with the aromatic ring of molecule 4 via Hg⋅⋅⋅π bond. The corresponding distances Hg(2)⋅⋅⋅Cg (where Cg is the centroid of the phenyl ring in 4) are 3.46 amd 3.48 Å , for aggregates of A and B, respectively.

elements.content: The molecules of II·4 are linked into chains (Figure c, d) via Hg···Cl interactions (Table ). These chains contain both aggregates A and B and are extended along crystallographic direction [100] (Figure d). In II·4 molecule 4 is bonded to only one molecule of Lewis acid, hence it probably does not contribute into any additional stabilization of these chains. In crystal these chains are linked via π···π stacking interactions between aromatic rings of II and 4 into layers, which are coplanar to the crystallographic plane ac (Figure e).
elements.clean_text: The molecules of II⋅4 are linked into chains (Figure c, d) via Hg⋅⋅⋅Cl interactions (Table ). These chains contain both aggregates A and B and are extended along crystallographic direction [100] (Figure d). In II⋅4 molecule 4 is bonded to only one molecule of Lewis acid, hence it probably does not contribute into any additional stabilization of these chains. In crystal these chains are linked via π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between aromatic rings of II and 4 into layers, which are coplanar to the crystallographic plane ac (Figure e).

elements.content: The IR spectra of complexes in Nujol display the ν(CO) as well as ν(C–O) bands. In all complexes studied ν(CO) bands are shifted to the lower wave numbers relative to the corresponding bands in the spectrum of noncoordinated ester (Table ). The ν(C–O) bands in complexes with aliphatic esters II·1 and 2(II)·2 are shifted to the higher wave numbers, while in complexes with aromatic esters these bands are shifted in the lower wave numbers.

IR Spectroscopy Data

The IR spectra of complexes in Nujol display the ν(CO) as well as ν(C-O) bands. In all complexes studied ν(CO) bands are shifted to the lower wave numbers relative to the corresponding bands in the spectrum of noncoordinated ester (Table ). The ν(C-O) bands in complexes with aliphatic esters II⋅1 and 2(II)⋅2 are shifted to the higher wave numbers, while in complexes with aromatic esters these bands are shifted in the lower wave numbers.

Δν(CO) = νuncoord(CO) – νcoord(CO); Δν(C–O) = νuncoord(C–O) – νcoord(C–O).

It is known that ν(CO) lines in vibration spectra of carbonyl compounds are very sensitive to the interaction of the CO bond with Lewis acids. The larger shift of this band (Δν(CO) = νuncoord(CO) – νcoord(CO)) to the lower wavenumber corresponds to the stronger interaction between Lewis acid and carbonyl compound. We presented the Δν(CO) as a function of the average Hg···O(1) contact distances in complexes II·1–II·4. In case of complex II·1 only Hg···O(1) distances in chelating fragment were considered. Results are presented in Figure a; it is seen from the graph, that the data points may be extrapolated with an exponential curve. Another way to present this dependence is a graph of natural logarithm of the Δν(CO) versus r(Hg···O) which is presented in Figure b. In the case of ln(Δν(CO)) the data points fit into linear function with correlation coefficient R 2 = 99.8%: ln ( Δ ν ( CO ) ) = − 5.597 r ( Hg···O ) + 19.610

elements.content: As was mentioned above the value of Δν(CO) may characterize an interaction energy between the ester and compound II. Therefore we can assume that if Δν(CO) < 1 cm–1 (or ln(Δν(CO)) < 0), there is probably no interaction between mercury atoms in II and carbonyl oxygen atom in the ester molecule. So at point where Δν(CO) = 1 cm–1 (or ln(Δν(CO)) = 0) the distance r 0(Hg···O) should be a shortest distance between noninteracting Hg and O atoms. Under such assumption from the eq the value of r 0(Hg···O) is equal to 3.50 Å, which is in fact close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O (3.54 Å).

elements.content: It was shown in our previous work that crystal shape of Lewis acid II adducts with nitro compounds reflects presence of strong layer- or chain-type supramolecular organization. Continuing this investigation the crystal morphology of individual LA II and adducts II·1-II·4 in terms of Miller indexes of faces using the APEX II diffractometer and APEX 2 software was eveluated.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Morphology

It was shown in our previous work that crystal shape of Lewis acid II adducts with nitro compounds reflects presence of strong layer- or chain-type supramolecular organization. Continuing this investigation the crystal morphology of individual LA II and adducts II⋅1-II⋅4 in terms of Miller indexes of faces using the APEX II diffractometer and APEX 2 software was eveluated.

elements.content: Crystal structure of II was studied earlier by Gabbai et al. Compound II crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with two symmetrically independent molecules A and B. Molecules of II are connected with Hg···Cl interactions forming molecular chains extended along crystallographic direction [010] (Figure a–c).
elements.clean_text: Crystal structure of II was studied earlier by Gabbai et al. Compound II crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with two symmetrically independent molecules A and B. Molecules of II are connected with Hg⋅⋅⋅Cl interactions forming molecular chains extended along crystallographic direction [010] (Figure a-c).

elements.content: (a) Molecular chain in crystal structure of II·3 along direction [010] and its (b) projection in plane (010) (molecules A, red; molecules B, blue). (c) Molecular packing of compound II.
elements.clean_text: 10  (a) Molecular chain in crystal structure of II⋅3 along direction [010] and its (b) projection in plane (010) (molecules A, red; molecules B, blue). (c) Molecular packing of compound II.

elements.content: Compound II was recrystallized from nitromethane as described in ref . Morphology of crystal II is presented in Figure a. The crystals of II have a needle-like shape with two “long” faces {100} and {001} along the main needle direction [010]. Thus, for crystal II morphology of its needle-like crystals reflects its internal supramolecular structure that contains chain-like associates of molecules extended along the [010] direction.
elements.clean_text: Compound II was recrystallized from nitromethane as described in ref . Morphology of crystal II is presented in Figure a. The crystals of II have a needle-like shape with two "long" faces {100} and {001} along the main needle direction [010]. Thus, for crystal II morphology of its needle-like crystals reflects its internal supramolecular structure that contains chain-like associates of molecules extended along the [010] direction.

elements.clean_text: 11  (a) Crystal morphology of compound II (a) and morphology of complexes (b) II⋅1, (c) 2(II)⋅2, (d) II⋅3, and (e) II⋅4.

elements.content: In case of the complexes II·1–II·4, we found a similar situation where morphology of crystals (Figures b-e) corresponds to the internal supramolecular structure of these complexes. Namely, the crystals of II·1 and II·3 with chain molecular associates (Figures and ) form needle-like crystals extended along directions [100] and [001] (Figure b, d) which correspond to direction of chains. The crystals of adducts 2(II)·2 and II·4 have a plate-like shape with most developed faces {102} and {001} (for crystals of 2(II)·2 and II·4) parallel to the molecular layers with indexes (102) and (001).
elements.clean_text: In case of the complexes II⋅1-II⋅4, we found a similar situation where morphology of crystals (Figures b-e) corresponds to the internal supramolecular structure of these complexes. Namely, the crystals of II⋅1 and II⋅3 with chain molecular associates (Figures  and ) form needle-like crystals extended along directions [100] and [001] (Figure b, d) which correspond to direction of chains. The crystals of adducts 2(II)⋅2 and II⋅4 have a plate-like shape with most developed faces {102} and {001} (for crystals of 2(II)⋅2 and II⋅4) parallel to the molecular layers with indexes (102) and (001).

elements.content: Structures of liquid at room temperatures aliphatic and aromatic esters 1–4 and their complexes with Lewis acid II were characterized with X-ray diffraction analysis, IR-spectroscopy and quantum calculations. It was found that complexes with aliphatic esters II·1 and 2(II)·2 have unusual dimeric sandwich structures. To the best of our knowledge such type of complexes for II was not reported before. It is remarkable that in the case of the 2(II)·2 the molecules 2 are linked to the mercury atoms of II not only via Hg···O interactions with carbonyl oxygen, but also via Hg···O interactions with ester oxygen atoms, that were not observed before in complexes of esters with Hg-organic compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Structures of liquid at room temperatures aliphatic and aromatic esters 1-4 and their complexes with Lewis acid II were characterized with X-ray diffraction analysis, IR-spectroscopy and quantum calculations. It was found that complexes with aliphatic esters II⋅1 and 2(II)⋅2 have unusual dimeric sandwich structures. To the best of our knowledge such type of complexes for II was not reported before. It is remarkable that in the case of the 2(II)⋅2 the molecules 2 are linked to the mercury atoms of II not only via Hg⋅⋅⋅O interactions with carbonyl oxygen, but also via Hg⋅⋅⋅O interactions with ester oxygen atoms, that were not observed before in complexes of esters with Hg-organic compounds.

elements.content: The main peculiarity of complexes with aromatic esters (3 and 4) is the presence of the Hg···π interactions in these complexes. These interactions in case of II·3 result in an additional stabilization of the molecular chains in crystal, and in the case of II·4, in the complex structure. Crystals of II·3 have acentric structure, which is another example of how supramolecular organization involving Hg nonbonded interactions might be helpful in producing acentric packing of polar molecules by incorporating them into similar mixed crystals.
elements.clean_text: The main peculiarity of complexes with aromatic esters (3 and 4) is the presence of the Hg⋅⋅⋅π interactions in these complexes. These interactions in case of II⋅3 result in an additional stabilization of the molecular chains in crystal, and in the case of II⋅4, in the complex structure. Crystals of II⋅3 have acentric structure, which is another example of how supramolecular organization involving Hg nonbonded interactions might be helpful in producing acentric packing of polar molecules by incorporating them into similar mixed crystals.

elements.content: The crystal morphology of the all complexes studied, as well as the shape of parent compound II, corresponds to their internal structure, namely, needle-like shape was found for crystals with chain (1D) supramolecular organization, while in the crystals having a plate like shape, molecules are linked into 2D layers.
elements.clean_text: The crystal morphology of the all complexes studied, as well as the shape of parent compound II, corresponds to their internal structure, namely, needle-like shape was found for crystals with chain (1D) supramolecular organization, while in the crystals having a plate like shape, molecules are linked into 2D layers.

elements.content: Analysis of the ν(CO) bands shifts in the IR-spectra of the esters (Δν(CO)) as a function of the Hg···O distances shows the exponential increase of the ν(CO) bands shifts to lower wave numbers region with deceasing of the Hg···O distances in complexes. Analysis of relation ln(Δν(CO)) versus r(Hg···O), shows that this function is linear. From this function, we found that minimal distance for interaction between carbonyl oxygen atom and mercury atoms of II is equal to 3.50 Å. This value is close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O (3.54 Å), and might be used in future for more detailed studies of contacts with additional interactions between the Hg and O atoms.

Analysis of relation ln(Δν(CO)) versus r(Hg⋅⋅⋅O), shows that this function is linear. From this function, we found that minimal distance for interaction between carbonyl oxygen atom and mercury atoms of II is equal to 3.50 Å. This value is close to the sum of the van der Waals radii of Hg and O (3.54 Å), and might be used in future for more detailed studies of contacts with additional interactions between the Hg and O atoms.
